repnme.cdata!: Brazil - Second Phase Bahia Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Phase Bahia
            Education Project for Brazil were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was high, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: Addressing the needs of marginalized populations.
            By the inclusion of the indigenous education sub-component
            in the Project was a learning opportunity for both the
            Secretariat of Education and Culture (SEC) and the Bank. The
            results of this component are considered very positive, both
            for the indigenous communities involved, as well as in the
            perceptions of local officials of improvements in
            relationships between these communities and local
            government. The impact study found that having a certified
            principal in a school was positively correlated with higher
            achievement. The idea of certification was also positively
            received by all groups interviewed as part of the
            beneficiary study. Providing ongoing certification
            opportunities for new principals and other education
            specialists may be an effective way to improve education
            quality. Accelerated classes. Given Bahia's staggering
            rates of age-grade distortion, the inclusion of accelerated
            classes in the Project could not have been more relevant. As
            demonstrated in the impact studies, these classes also made
            a significant contribution towards improvement in this
            regard. With age-grade distortion in the fundamental cycle
            now estimated as standing at 45.6 percent, continuing with
            accelerated classes deserves serious consideration.

abstracts.cdata!:
The purpose of the Bahia Education
            Program for Brazil is to assist the Government of Bahia in
            its effort to improve the educational system and respond to
            the demands and needs of the Bahian population. The program
            complements numerous Government actions and focuses on
            improving fundamental' and secondary school quality,
            increasing access to secondary schools, and improving system
            management. The program is designed as a 5 year effort; The
            development objectives of the Second Bahia Education Program
            are to: (a) improve fundamental and secondary school
            outcomes, as measured by improvements in dropout and
            promotion rates and student performance on standardized
            tests; and (b) increase access to secondary school, as
            measured by an increase in secondary enrollments. There are
            three project components with several subcomponents.
            Component 1 supports the improvement of school, quality by
            assuring minimum operational standards for schools,
            supporting the implementation of school development plans,
            financing school improvement projects, implementing
            accelerated classes, expanding Gestar (a curriculum and
            in-service teacher training program developed by Fundescola
            and aligned with the new National Curriculum parameters),
            and improving indigenous education. Component 2 expands
            access to education by planning and providing additional
            school places through construction of additional classrooms.
            Component 3 strengthens educational management by
            strengthening educational assessment, strengthening
            educational management institutions, financing project
            management, and funding project monitoring and impact evaluation.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Bahia Education Program (Phase 2)
            Project : indigenous peoples plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bahia Education Program (Phase 2)
            Project aims at improving the quality of education in the
            State, with the inclusion of indigenous populations in
            remote areas. This Indigenous Peoples Plan (IPP)
            specifically looks at the legislation concerning the
            approach to indigenous peoples' education, its
            diagnosis, directives, objectives, and goals. Within this
            framework of new dynamics and concepts of education,
            legislation incorporates the inclusion of indigenous
            populations to the national official system of education,
            bearing due respect to their culture, and traditions. This
            IPP addresses in particular the curricula for indigenous
            schools, and identifies the study areas, and main themes as
            follows: a) curricula will consider indigenous pedagogy, the
            history of education, psychology of education, as well as
            educational management; 2) regarding society, nature, and
            culture, the themes will address socio-anthropological
            aspects, and historic, geographic, and natural science
            aspects, taking into account the time-space factors,
            biodiversity, and territorial knowledge; 3) regarding
            language, bilingual education will emphasize both maternal,
            and national languages, in addition to including education
            in the arts of varied societies - music, crafts, etc.; 4)
            mathematics will initially focus on the native systems of
            measures, and numerals. Courses will be available for
            indigenous teachers training, and would include a spectrum
            of themes, from past, present, and future earth and land
            aspects, to productive systems, health and education,
            biodiversity and culture, within both theoretical and
            practical levels.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Bahia Education (Phase 02) Project
            : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Bahia Education (Phase II) Project
            will improve the quality of, and access to primary and
            secondary education, which includes access to education by
            indigenous populations in remote areas, with the subsequent
            construction of schools. This environmental assessment (EA)
            first considers the site selection criteria, and the
            technical specifications for each architectural project, to
            comply with the country's environmental regulations,
            and the Bank's operational directive on the
            environment. Considerations include adversity on critical
            natural habitats, the potential for land flooding, adversity
            to local populations as a result of construction and damage
            to existing infrastructure - electricity, water supply,
            access roads - as well as surface, and groundwater
            contamination. The criteria for environmental mitigation,
            outline measures as follows. Sites selection would avoid
            flood prone areas, and as possible natural habitats, in an
            effort to preserve biodiversity, and natural water flows.
            The standard school designs will address sanitation in
            particular, to include toilets, and adequate sanitary
            measures. Protective barriers will be installed to contain
            soil erosion, and divert water flows which might potentially
            endanger construction, based on hydrological studies, and
            geological data conducted for the implementation of each
            specific project. Drainage systems will be surveyed to
            monitor rainwater, surface, and groundwater to contain
            erosion, and in addition, as sanitary control, and hygiene
            monitoring to prevent water contamination, while septic
            tanks will also be installed. Construction contracts would
            include precautionary clauses to ensure adequate disposal of
            debris, including toxic residues, oil spillage, and
            hazardous chemicals. Vegetation propagation will be
            practiced following construction, to maintain and increase
            the local flora and fauna, and to control erosion, and air
            pollution, but in accordance with strict selection of native
            species, adequate to local soil nutrients. Finally,
            architectural choices will respect cultural heritage sites,
            and, contractors should inform the archaeological
            authorities, should discoveries of historical or cultural
            value occur.
